title: AtoZ CSS News
subject_line: Is CSS dead? AtoZ CSS News special
tag_line: My favourite articles and news plus a new CSS tip
intro_text: There's been a lot of talk recently (especially in the React JS community) about the future of CSS - the new idea being that we don't need CSS and we should do everything in JavaScript. I've hunted down 5 great links on the subject so you can see which side of the fence you land. I think the idea is very interesting and could be great for very dynamic apps but I think CSS will definitely still have a place for styling content and adding visual enhancements like animations to sites for a good while yet. I'd love to hear your thoughts though!

news.link_comment: This is what kicked off my digging in to this topic (prompted by a tweet from @kurtjc). Nicole Sullivan, Jeremy Keith, Jed Schmidt and Colin Megill join Chris and Dave to discuss this topic in depth - with a surprising lack of Hot Drama!

news.link_text: Do We Even Need CSS Anymore?
news.link_comment: Chris does a great job of explaining the issues in CSS that have prompted a move to injecting inline styles with JS along with some of the benefits to doing this. This is a great place to start in finding out what all the fuss is about.

news.link_text: Inline Styles Are About To Kill CSS
news.link_comment: In this video from CSS Conf, Colin Megill (also on the Shoptalk panel) proposes that JavaScript is the future of CSS - especially for rich interactive applications. By this point, I'm starting to come round to the idea but still think CSS has it's place and is a much easier on-ramp for those new to web design/development.

If you're a React developer and like the sound of this new approach, you may want to check out Radium, a set of tools to manage inline styles on React elements. It gives you powerful styling capabilities without CSS and was built by Formidable Labs. They do a great job of explaining the how and what along with some Codepen demos. Definitely an interesting read.

news.link_text: React Inline Styles are Fundamentally Flawed
news.link_comment: Joey Baker disagrees (at least in part) and outlines why: no media queries, no @keyframes, no cascading styles and potentially performance issues.
